trial_identification.studytitle: Changes in the forward head position after the application of osteopathic technique "Thumb-move" at D1 level.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Changes in the value of craniovertebral angle pre-post intervention after the implementation of the bilateral thumb-move technique compared with placebo in cyclists with forward head position.

conditions.healthcondition: Postural changes, particularly: forward head position.

interventions.interventions:
Osteopathic manipulative treatment of C7-T1. Administered only once from each side at the level T1, by a trained physiotherapist with with 11 years of experience and training in osteopathy in accordance with European standards of 1400 hours.
Description of intervention:
Position the patient: prone. Position of the Therapist: standing, up to the patient's chest on the left side first and then the right.
Contacts: A hand comes into contact with the thumb on the side of the spinous process of T1, by taking skin fold of the trapezius with the rest of the hand. The forearm is placed perpendicular to the spine. The other hand on the temporary contact who has his head turned the opposite side to the hand that manipulates.
Parameters: we must put some extent, being careful not to lose double chin to protect the upper cervical. Then you rotate and set the head on the table.
Implementation: realization of thrust, direction from outside to inside, ballistic with short-range, with your thumb on the spine. And repeat on the other side.
Duration of intervention one minute both sides.
interventions.comparator: Control group subjects received a placebo technique, is to be placed in the same position with the same therapist contacts, the same time that its takes the true technique, but without manipulation, only with slight tension.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Craniovertebral angle. Data was collected via lateral photographs, and was then measured in degrees directly between a horizontal line transecting the spinous process of the seventh cervical vertebra and a line connecting the tragus of the ear with the spinous process of the seventh cervical vertebra.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Before, after and fifteen minutes after intervention.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Strength of the flexors and extensors of the head as assessed using a digital hand dynamometer.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Before, after and fifteen minutes after intervention

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Hand strength as assessed using the digital Grip dynamometer.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Before, after and fifteen minutes after intervention

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Pain sensitivity changes as assessed using a digital Algometer.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Before, after and fifteen minutes after intervention.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Cervical range of motion as assessed using a digital inclinometer.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Before, after and fifteen minutes after intervention.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Forced Expiratory Volume in the first second of expiration (FEV1), and the Forced Expiratory Volume in the first six seconds of expiration (FEV6) as assessed using an expiratory flow meter.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Before, after and fifteen minutes after intervention.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: 1 - Patients who give consent in writing. 2 - Male or female aged between 18 and 55. 3 - With forward head position. 4 - Cyclists who practice more than three years of cycling and an activity of at least 4 hours per week. 5 - who had not received osteopathic treatment of the spine, at least two months in advance. 6 - which there is no exclusionary criteria
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: 1 - Orthopedic test Kleyn or JacksonÂ´s positive. 2 - Some type of contraindication to manual therapy and more specifically to techniques for intervention; unresolved cancer process, severe osteoporosis, cervical arthritis, advanced infection or ongoing inflammation, congenital malformations, etc. 3 - Patients with mechanical neck pain secondary to: acute whiplash, rheumatoid arthritis, cervical arthritis advanced cervical myelopathy or other diseases. 4 - radiculalgia cervicobrachial associated with disc herniation or protrusion of the lower cervical spine. 5.- Patients with serious hormonal imbalance diagnosed.

trial_design.concealment: Subjects are recruited to the cycling federation, assigned to the control group or the intervention group tossing a coin at the time of submission of the study, face of the coin is the control group and cross is the intervention group. An investigator performing the technique or placebo intervention and then another researcher who does not know which group the subject, making measurements
trial_design.sequence: Simple randomisation, assigned to the control group or the intervention group tossing a coin at the time of submission of the study, then, face is the control group and cross is the intervention group.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The forward head position is a common posture imbalance that causes a variety of musculoskeletal pathologies. There is evidence of the impact, we have reliable methods, noninvasive, in order to measure the position of the head relative to the cervical spine, there are also studies showing effective techniques to improve this imbalance of posture. But still many other techniques to be evaluated and one of them is studied in this research.
